The city of Kobe has a beautiful harbor area and has been a popular attraction for both Japanese and foreign visitors. Total walking time will be 30 to 40 minutes. Tour duration will be 120 to 150 minutes.
strTitle: Take a Casual Sake (Rice Wine) Brewery Tour in Kobe area

strIntroduction: Let's have fun and relaxed time going out in Sapporo! This activity will help you feel the local Japanese style of life and socialize with locals. Here is a short example of the schedule: 19:00 - I meet you at your hotel or in the center of Sapporo 19:20 - We arrive at the restaurant We eat, chat, drink, and have a great time together! 21:30 - The tour finishes. If you want to go to another place (an izakaya bar or a pub), you can go with me. If you want to go back to your hotel, I will take you to your hotel. For Spanish: Por ejemple 19:00 quedamos en su hotel o centro de sapporo. 19:20 Llegamos a restaurante comer, comunicar, disfrutar... 21:30 acabamos si quiera ir otro (bar..), vamos. si quiere volver a hotel.volveramos con me.
strTitle: Experience the best Sapporo izakaya and sushi restaurants!

strIntroduction: In this tour I will take you to three of Tokyo's most famous and bustling shopping streets: - Nakamise street in Asakusa - Ameyoko street in Ueno - Takeshita street in Harajuku As three of the best known shopping streets they are all super crowded which you can see on my photos. Here is a short introduction of the streets: Nakamise street is for traditional Japanese goods and interesting souvenirs. It's the best place in Tokyo to buy gifts from your trip. Ameyoko Street offers various kinds of local foods and discounted items for every taste. Takeshita street specializes in Japanese young people's fashion. If you want to join this tour, be ready for walking through very crowded streets for more than an hour. However, this is an important and interesting part of the Japanese culture that you can explore together with me. Free Option: I have a single-lens reflex camera. Let me know if you want me to take your photos during the tour.
strTitle: Visit three of Tokyo's most famous shopping streets!

strIntroduction: Yuki-tsumugi is a high-grade silk textile fashioned in a folk art style via techniques handed down from the Nara period (8th century). All the work is done by hand, from the spinning to the actual weaving. The process yields silk with a unique texture and the highest possible quality. Here is the example itinerary of this tour: 9:00 I pick you up at Shinjuku Station and take you to Yuki city in Ibaraki prefecture. 12:00 Lunch time. We will go to a famous local restaurant. 13:00 We will visit the folklore village Tsumugi no Sato. Besides seeing and learning more about traditional local crafts, you will have the chance to try hands-on experiences of weaving in the traditional old Yuki-tsumugi style. 15:00-16:00 Visit Takeda-Suga Shrine. Buy a local Japanese Sake, Buyuu as a souvenir. (by the way, it is my favorite!) 16:00 Go back to Tokyo. I drop you off at Shinjyuku Station.
strTitle: Try traditional Yuki-Tsumugi weaving!

strIntroduction: Guests can participate in a tea ceremony class at a tea master's home, followed by visits to Japanese specialty shops of green tea and wagashi (Japanese sweets). You will enjoy Matcha (ground green tea) and wagashi at the tea ceremony as well as a sampling of various green teas and wagashi at the shops. Here are the details of the tour: Basic Plan： [12:30～12:45] Meet at Toritsu-Daigaku Station. Welcomed by an English-speaking interpreter. Participants take a short car ride as they are guided to classroom. [12:45～13:40] Tea ceremony class: Go on a journey to free your mind through the ritual of tea! Enjoy the finest quality green tea and traditional Japanese sweets from famous confectioneries. Try out for yourself the unique and fun Japanese way of making green tea. Learn about tea utensils, hanging scrolls, and the etiquette of flower arrangements. [13:40～13:55] Walk from the tea ceremony classroom to a tea shop. [13:55～14:25] Visit specialty green tea and Japanese sweets shops. Souvenirs are available for buying! Doien tea shop - Includes green tea sampling! Participants are taken to this shop specializing in green tea, a commodity now experiencing a worldwide boom due to the increasing interest in healthy living and Japanese food. Hachinoya traditional Japanese confectionery – Includes japanese sweets sampling! Participants are taken to this specialty Japanese confectionery, which creates beautiful traditional sweets carefully prepared by artisans with selected ingredients. [14:25～14:30] Tour ends at Toritsu-Daigaku Station. Interpreter escorts participants to station. Optional Plan： [14:30～14:40] Participants take a short car ride as they are guided to ceramics shop. [14:40～15:25] Visit specialty ceramics shops. Souvenirs available! Gallery Yakimono Naganawa Japanese ceramics and pottery shop. Participants are taken to this pottery shop carrying a vast selection of tableware suitable for use in the tea ceremony or with Japanese cuisine (now a registered UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage). [15:25～15:30] Tour ends at Gakugei-Daigaku Station. The Interpreter escorts the participants to the station. The participants walk along a charming shopping district to the station. Participants walk along a charming shopping district to the station. Special Services: Photos taken during this tour are later given as a present to participants over the internet. Important! If your group is between 2 and 4 people, you need to book also the add-on for a private tour.
strTitle: Enjoy Green Tea and Wagashi Delights

strIntroduction: This is a night life tour in some of Tokyo's best known bustling areas. In this tour we will visit: (1) Shibuya Crossing Street - meeting at Shibuya Station. Let's take photos at the famous busy Shibuya crossing! (2) Beer Museum in Ebisu Ebisu is famous for Ebisu beer, one of Japan's best beer brands. So let's visit the Ebisu Beer Museum and taste some local beer! (3) Japanese local bars at Ebisu Let's eat and drink at a Japanese tiny local bar! You can taste sashimi or assorted chicken BBQ dishes. Of course, you can drink Japanese sake as well! If you are interested, going to a cat cafe can also be a good idea for an optional visit. In this tour you can experience both modern and local atmosphere in Tokyo during the same day. Come and join me for a night tour! Available during the weekends!
strTitle: Go out in Shibuya - Ebisu Beer museum & local bar night

strIntroduction: Takunomi is a style of home parties popular between Japanese young people nowadays. The main reason for its popularity is that it is inexpensive and comfortable. How about joining a drinking meeting at my house? I like a cooking. I can prepare the following: * Onigiri. * Yakitori. * Yakisoba. * Japanese style salad It isn't a lot, but the appetizers are delicious. I will have prepared Japan's famous beer and sake in my house. Important details about the tour: * Time is limited from 7:00 pm to 9:00 pm. * The number of people is up to 4 people. * You can't stay overnight. * Please be sure to return to your hotel in time. * Food and a drinks are included in the price. * If you'd like to eat and drink much, you have to book the option charge. * If the alcohol is all consumed, extra charge may apply to buy more.
strTitle: Japanese style home drinking party "Takunomi"

strIntroduction: If you are looking for a nice izakaya (drink & eat bar) and want to talk with local person at Shizuoka city, I surely think that I am useful. Shizuoka is not so internationalized city, so even at shops people have a tendency to be shy to foreign travelers, and worry about language or communication with foreign people. I want to support you and these shops, and want to introduce you to nice local meals, while we have an enjoyable time! I can introduce you to really delicious and comfortable Izakaya bars! Let's have a enjoyable time! Starting time is flexible. We can start for example at 17:30-18:00 and go to Izakaya until 20:00-20:30. This is a private tour for your group (no other people to join). The meal and drinks are not included in the price (it's a habit in Izakaya that the bill is split equal between the people on the table). If you want to go to another bar after Izakaya I will recommend you some, although I will not join you. If you want to go to a Ramen restaurant, I will recommend you some places offering: 1. tonkotsu, 2. gyokai-soysauce 3. yokohama-iekei Come and enjoy the city together with me!
strTitle: Let's drink together at the center of Shizuoka city!

strIntroduction: Kushiro Shitsugen National Park, one of the largest in Japan, consists of a vast marshland dotted with small lakes and observatories for watching the wildlife. The Japanese crane is particularly famous and this national park is known as the natural habitat of the elegant wild bird. Kushiro River winds along the wetland and offers plenty of opportunities for slow-paced canoeing which allows you to explore the wildlife of the national park. In this activity you can choose between paddling a private canoe for two for about 9 kilometers down the Kushiro River or renting a group canoe and paddling together with your friends and family. The stream is calm and ideal even for first-time experience on a canoe. You will be instructed by a professional guide who will accompany you along your way down the river. Snacks and drinks are included. Please wear comfortable clothes for outdoor activities in the river. It's recommended to wear long sleeves as to avoid insect bites. Please wear a hat and apply sunscreen in order to protect from the sun. You bear responsibility for the valuables you take with you on the canoe. This activity is offered between May 1 and October 31. The private course for two takes between 3 and 3 and a half hours. The group course takes between 2 and 2 and a half hours; it accommodates up to 7 people. Initial instruction will take place at Lake Toro before paddling down Kushiro River until Hosooka.
strTitle: Paddle a canoe down the Kushiro River in the marshland!

strIntroduction: Lake Akan is one of the three famous caldera lakes of Akan National Park. It is widely known as the home of "marimo", a peculiar green ball-shaped algae species. The entire area is a natural habitat of many wild birds, fish and plants which makes it attractive for lovers of green and eco-tourism. One of the best ways to explore the wildlife and biodiversity of this area is to paddle a Canadian canoe between the common reed near the shores of Lake Akan! You can choose between a short introduction course and a 2-hour adventure course for pairs. A professional guide will teach you how to paddle the canoe and will give you rental equipment. Along the way you will see plenty of fallen trees, common reed and rare species of wild birds. Free drinks and snacks are included in this tour! This tour is offered every day between May 1 and October 31. The introductory course is offered for 45 minutes and starts at one of the following times (according to your preferences): - 6:30 am, 7:30 am, 11:30 am, 3:30 pm The adventure course takes two hours and is offered in the morning (from 9:00) and in the afternoon (from 13:00). Please wear comfortable clothes for outdoor activities in the lake. Long sleeves are recommended to avoid insect bites. Please wear a hat and apply sunscreen to protect from the sun. You bear responsibility for your valuables you're taking with you in the canoe.
strTitle: Go canoeing in Lake Akan, part of Akan National Park!

strIntroduction: In this activity you will visit a Japanese house in Osaka and learn how to cook popular Japanese dishes! Our class schedule is as follows: Saturday (10:30--13:00) Sunday (10:30-13:00) Monday (10:30-13:00) Each class takes about 2.5 hours. However, you can request different times for this activity. We will do our best to accommodate your requests. Here is a list of some of the dishes that you can learn to prepare: 1. Bento box (rice + egg+vegetables+minced "katsu" cutlet or karaage friend chicken or tonkatsu pork cutlet+ umegoshi) 2. B Set Meal - Tempura Set & Sauce (tempura+rice+miso soup) 3.Japanese Beef Curry (rice+ salad) 4. Okonomiyaki ( 2 pieces per each person) Note: If you're vegetarian or you're interested in making any other dishes, please contact us and ask. We will do our best to respond to your requests! We will meet you at the north bus terminal of JR Amagasaki Station (just one station away from Osaka Station). We will give you more information when you book this activity. Other people might join too. In such cases this activity will be a group lesson.
strTitle: Home Cooking Class! Learn to make everyday Japanese food!

strIntroduction: In this activity you can enjoy strolling around Tokyo dressed in a Kimono or Yukata! Our shop is located at Meguro, Tokyo. You can walk to Meguro riverside, or visit Meguro Gajoen, which is famous as the first ever wedding hall in Japan and has a beautiful traditional Japanese building. It is within 7 minute walking distance from our studio. Also, Shibuya is 5 minutes away by train! Harajuku and Meiji Jingu Shinto Shrine are 10 minutes away by train. Please go and enjoy having lunch, shopping, and sightseeing in kimono! Our kimonos are very "kawaii" (pretty and cute) in a fashionable retro style. Rental available time: 10 am - 5 pm. Please return to our studio by 5 pm. Our very friendly staff is waiting for you every day!
strTitle: Enjoy Harajuku, Meiji Jingu, or anywhere in Kimono all day!

strIntroduction: This activity is a glimpse into the practices of Japanese Buddhist priests. We offer several different options: ●Overall Course (about 2 hours), which includes: 1. Explanation (5 min) 2. Prayers (15 min) 3. Worship (15 min) 4. Sutra recitation (15 min) 5. Writing of sutra (20 min) 6. Invocation of Namu Amida Butsu (15 min) 7. Trying on the priest’s garb (20 min) ●Simple Course (about 30 min) 1. Explanation (5 min) 2. You can choose one of the following activities (25 min): Prayers, Worship, Sutra recitation, Writing of sutra, Invocation of Namu Amida Butsu, Trying on the priest’s garb Description of the activities: “Prayers“ is a ritual in which a priest prays for your good life and seals the wish in an amulet. You can take the amulet home with you. “Worship” is an ascetic practice for clearing your mind by taking exercises like squatting and reciting “Namu Amida Butsu”, a type of sutra. It can be physically challenging! “Sutra recitation” is a practice in which you exclusively read sutras as “Hannyashingyo” and others aloud using a “Mokugyo” (a wooden drum used in a Buddhist temple) Writing of sutra is a practice in which you copy down “Hannyashingyo” and others. You can get in touch with the “Kanji” culture. You can take home the sheets of paper you copy sutras on. “Invocation of Namu Amida Butsu” is a practice to clear your mind by repeating “Namu Amida Butsu”, a type of sutra, over and over. “Trying on the priest’s garb” - you can transform into a priest! You can book this activity from 06:00 to 20:00 every day. Please choose your preferred time. After the Japanese Buddhism practice, you can eat meal at a local “Izakaya” restaurant “Asahi”, which is famous in the area.
strTitle: Experience Japanese Buddhist practice

strIntroduction: Akan National Park is a wide area which comprises of three big caldera lakes - Lake Mashu, Lake Kussharo and Lake Akan, as well as several volcanic mountains (Mt Iozan, Mt Meakan, Mt Oakan) and a few cozy little hot spring towns. This park is one of the most well-preserved natural eco-systems in Hokkaido and is widely known for its pristine beauty and breathtaking picturesque views. Access to and around the lakes is difficult to non-existent by public transportation, but in this tour you will be taken to some of the most famous natural spots where you can make some of the best photos during your trip in Hokkaido. This is not a classical guided tour, as the beauty of the area speaks for itself and does not necessitate explanation. The itinerary can be customized according to your preferences, however some of our recommendations are: - Lake Mashu, known as one of the clearest caldera lakes in the world. The still water surface is often veiled by fog but you can nevertheless take some amazing photos at two of the observatories located on top of the hills surrounding the western side of the lake. - Mt Iozan, an active volcano spectacular for its bare rock surface dotted with sulfurous vents. The smell of surface and the yellow colour of the rocks will certainly impress you. Don't forget to try hot spring eggs boiled on the volcano's steams. - Lake Kussharo, the biggest of the three lakes and best known for its multiple hot springs around the shores. Particularly interesting is the sand beach where you can scoop a hole in the sand and feel the hot water coming from beneath. - 900 Sogen, a picturesque rest house on the top of a tall hill from which you can enjoy a splendid panorama view of the entire park. - Lake Akan, the western lake and home to marimo, a rare species of algae shaped like green balls. You can visit unique mud bubble baths and walk along an open air museum of the indigenous Ainu people. Please note that the itinerary should be discussed in advance. The time for pick-up and drop-off is included in the tour time.
strTitle: Visit the most scenic photo spots of Akan National Park

strIntroduction: Just as Kyoto's many temples and shrines are an important part of its long-established culture, maiko are a traditional part of the history of Kyoto as well. In this activity, you will have the rare opportunity to both photograph the maiko as she performs a traditional dance and enjoy spending time with her. This activity is available every once a month. For more information, please look at the calendar. Photo Session Schedule: 12:15: Meet at the photo session venue Guests will learn about the day's photo shoot schedule. 12:30 - 14:30: Photo Shoot Meet the maiko. The maiko will perform a traditional dance. Enjoy exclusive time to shoot the maiko alone. Engage in conversation and take photos together with the maiko. 14:30: End of Photo Shoot Select a few photos taken on the day to be shared on the photo sharing website site ’Flickr’, which is widely used in the world.
strTitle: Enjoy an exclusive photo session with a Maiko in Kyoto

strIntroduction: Lake Shikotsu is located about an hour ride away from Sapporo and is a popular natural spot for recreation. Part of Shikotsu-Toya National Park, the lake was formed from earth collapses after intensive volcanic activity. Mt Tarumae, one of Japan's most active volcanoes, stands just beside Lake Shikotsu and is also a popular hiking spot for lovers of extreme volcanic experiences. In this activity your guide will pick you up from Sapporo and will take you to Lake Shikotsu where you will ride canoe over the lake! Afterwards, your guide will take you on a pleasant natural trekking around the lake. You will see wild birds, flowers and animals, and will fully enjoy the tranquil nature of Lake Shikotsu! This activity is only available during the green season (between May and September). A minimum of 2 people are required. Don't miss your chance to see the picturesque views of one of Hokkaido's best caldera lakes!
strTitle: Explore Lake Shikotsu on a canoe and trekking!

strIntroduction: This activity includes observing and even participating in Nago Fish Market's fish auction! Afterwards you will go to a local bar and make your own fresh sushi to eat from the fish you got in the auction! This is a great activity for couples and families who would like to try fresh seafood in Okinawa! Here are the details of the activity: Meeting place: Nago city, Nago Fish Market bidding venue Meeting time: 8:30 am Watch the auction for about an hour. Before that the local guide will explain to you the bidding process and you will be able to choose a fish from the colourful array. During the auction you might win the fish (please pay for it yourself). The rest of the tour takes place in the afternoon: Meeting place: Yuuyakeichiba bar in Nago Meeting time: 16:00 Here the sushi chef will show you how to make sushi yourself. Cut the fish you won in pieces and try to make fresh sushi under the guidance of the professional chef. This will take about 1-1.5 hours and you will be able to eat your own sushi! Enjoy your day in Nago, Okinawa!
strTitle: Watch Fish Auction and Make Sushi in Nago, Okinawa

strIntroduction: Okuhida is a mountainous region located on the border of Gifu and Nagano prefectures, and is part of the Japanese Alps. Here you can see some of the most scenic views in Japan - narrow valleys with hot spring towns embraced by impressive high mountains with snow-covered slopes. You will ride the unique double-decked Shin-Hotaka Ropeway - the largest and the highest in Japan! In fact, there are two different ropeway rides, the second of which climbs over 1000 meters up the mountain range! The view from the top is truly fascinating! This activity is a 1-day coupon ticket to be used at Shin-Hotaka's facilities. It includes: - a round-trip ropeway ride - lunch and shopping tickets for up to 1500 JPY (3 coupons worth 500 JPY each that you can exchange for lunch and souvenirs at the visitor center) - entrance to "Kamitakara no Yu", the open-air natural hot spring at Nabedaira Station, or the hot spring of Hotel Hotaka next to the bottom ropeway station. The opening times are: - Shin-Hotaka Ropeway: 8:00 (in summer) or 9:00 (in winter) to 16:45 (in summer) or 16:15 (in winter) - "Kamitakara no Yu" hot spring: 9:30 to 15:30 - Hotel Hotaka hot spring: 13:00 to 15:00 Enjoy one day surrounded by the impressive nature of Okuhida region!
strTitle: Explore the natural beauty of Shin-Hotaka and hot springs!

strIntroduction: Naruto in Tokushima prefecture is often considered the entrance to Shikoku island, as it's the closest located city to Osaka, Kobe and Kyoto. Naruto is famous for its natural phenomenon of impressive whirlpools formed in the Straits of Naruto just outside of the city's main center and under Onaruto Bridge which links Shikoku to Awaji island. Naruto is also the home of the first temple from the Shikoku Pilgrimage (which tours a total of 88 temples in the entire island). In this private guided tour you will see some of Naruto's most famous highlights: - Naruto Whirlpools, the unique symbol of the city.The whirlpools are formed at the place where the Pacific Ocean tides meet the Seto Inland Sea tides. In general the whirlpools appear seasonally and are most visible twice a day during the warm part of the year. Please ask in advance about the best time to see the whirlpools on the day of your visit. You will see them from "Uzu no Michi", a long glass corridor under the Onaruto Bridge. There are also some very good observatories from the seaside park, as well as a small museum explaining the natural formation of the whirlpools. - Ryozenji Temple, the first of the 88 temples of the Shikoku Pilgrimage. Here you will learn more about the practices of the pilgrimage. You can also buy white robes, woven hats and other items which pilgrims use during their trip around Shikoku. - the German House and German Village, a splendid museum which used to be a prison for German soldiers captured in the Pacific colonies during the World War I when Japan and Germany were enemies. Although not included in this tour, Naruto city is home to Japan's biggest art gallery - Otsuka Museum of Art - which has hundreds of reproductions of famous Western paintings. Please ask your guide about the museum if you're interested to visit it after the tour.
strTitle: Explore Naruto, the city of whirlpools at Shikoku's entrance

strIntroduction: Arita town in Saga prefecture developed as Japan's most important pottery center after the shogun brought Korean craftsmen and experts to Kyushu island in the 17th century. After the discovery of kaolin in a quarry near Arita the town's porcelain production prospered and the pottery art began to be exported internationally. The porcelain of Arita quickly became popular in Europe, particularly in France. Nowadays there are many sightseeing spots and museums in the town related to the traditions of the local pottery. This half-day private guided tour is ideal for lovers of fine art and Japan's top-class pottery products. You can make a short stop on your way from Fukuoka to Nagasaki and learn more about the fascinating legacy of the potters in Saga. Here is a list of interesting places you will see in Arita: - Izumiyama Quarry, the original site of the discovery of kaolin in Arita. You can see the large quarry from an observation deck. - Tonbai wall street in Uchiyama, otherwise known as the district of the potters. During the Edo period the potters used to live in residences encircled by large brick walls in order to hide their techniques from competitors. The walls themselves are fascinating because they're made of pieces of pottery and porcelain. - Tozan Shrine, a unique 17th century shrine whose mane gate and statues of guardian dogs are made entirely of porcelain! - Tengudani Kiln, the original site of one of Arita's first kilns built along a 50-meter long slope. - Arita Porcelain Park, a unique facility located just outside of downtown Arita where you can see a reconstruction of the entire Zwinger Palace of Dresden, the original Arita kiln, and a big exhibition of porcelain art. - Kyushu Ceramic Arts Museum, a beautiful museum displaying many art items and ceramics from all over Kyushu. You can also try to make your own pottery in some of the crafts ateliers around the town, however you will not be able to take back the item with you as it takes long time until the baking is complete.
strTitle: See the porcelain town Arita and find Japan's best pottery!

strIntroduction: Tottori's Sand Dunes and the natural desert they form are among Japan's most bizarre and unique places. The desert spans for nearly 16 kilometers and some of the sand dunes are 50-meter high. The landscape changes with the wind and the silence is disturbed only by the sound of the nearby sea waves. This amazing place offers plenty of opportunities for outdoor activities such as paragliding, sandboarding and camel riding. Although Tottori is the least populated prefecture in Japan, its capital city has some remarkable sightseeing places. In this tour you will see the famous desert and the city's best highlights: - Tottori Sand Dunes, the naturally formed desert right next to the sea where you can climb the high dunes (it's a lot harder and slower than you'd expect!). Here you can also ride a camel for a short walk around the dunes. - The Sand Museum, a splendid indoor exhibition of sand art. The giant sand sculptures are changed every year and the exhibition has a different theme with each change. - Tottori Castle Ruins and Jinpukaku. The castle belonged to the local Ikeda feudal lord, but was destroyed after the end of the shogunate. Nowadays only part of the wall has been preserved and you can climb the hill for a good panorama view over the city. The nearby Jinpukaku Residence makes a nice contrast to the medieval castle. It was one of the first Western-style buildings in Tottori which has now been turned into a museum. - Kannonin Temple, a Buddhist temple with a splendid Japanese-style garden. You can take a rest with a cup of tea and enjoy the tranquil beauty of the garden. Tottori is among Japan's little-known gems. A visit to this city and the unique sand dunes will make for an unforgettable trip!
strTitle: Ride a camel on the sand dunes of Tottori's desert!

strIntroduction: Yamadera (official name Risshakuji) is one of the most popular mountain temples in Japan, a true symbol of the scenic image that many people associate rural Japan with. It is located just outside Yamagata city in Yamagata prefecture, and though it can be visited in day trip from Tokyo, a stay in the countryside area is more recommended. Yamadera is a large temple complex consisting of half a dozen buildings, treasure halls and gates built along the slopes of the mountains northeast of the city. The temple was founded in 860, around the beginning of the expansion towards the far north, by the Buddhist priest Jikaku Daishi. If you're confident in your ability to climb all the 1000 or so steps to the top, the panorama view will be very rewarding. You can choose between a half-day tour visiting Yamadera only, or a full day privately guided tour which will also cover interesting historical highlights of Yamagata city. The following is the list of places to visit: - Yamadera Temple, all the way from the Konponchudo Hall located at the bottom of the mountain to the picturesque Kaisando Hall built on a cliff at the top. Your guide will tell you the history of the temple and will show you interesting places related to the famous haiku poet Matsuo Basho who visited this area in the 17th century and wrote some of his popular haiku poems here. The view from the top will fascinate you! - Fuga no Kuni, a small shopping and entertainment complex where you can see an exhibition of folklore art and instruments used daily by the people from the past. You can also buy Yamagata's local food products here. If you choose the full-day tour, you will also visit several other places in Yamagata city, such as: - Yamagata Castle, also known as Kajo Castle. Only parts of it and the gates remain in the spacious park now, but there are plans to reconstruct it completely. - Yamagata Kyodokan and Bunshokan, impressive Meiji-style buildings with modern architecture now turned into museums and cultural halls. - Nanokamachi Gotenzeki, a pleasant old street with a stone-paved waterway in the middle. You can visit Yamadera as a day trip from Tokyo or from Sendai. Join this tour and see the most popular mountain temple view in Japan!
strTitle: Climb to the top of Japan's most scenic hill temple Yamadera

strIntroduction: Hiraizumi in Iwate prefecture was the northern base of the powerful Fujiwara clan which ruled the entire country during the Heian period (9-13 century). The Fujiwara rulers attempted to exceed the brilliance and importance of the capital Kyoto by building impressive temples and copying some of Kyoto's famous landmarks. After the Fujiwara rule declined, the city was conquered and almost completely destroyed by Japan's first shogun Minamoto Yoritomo. Nevertheless some of Hiraizumi's cultural and architectural monuments remained to remind of the city's past glory. In 2011 Hiraizumi was registered as a UNESCO World Cultural Heritage Site. In this full-day guided tour you will visit Hiraizumi's most famous sites and will learn more about the tragic events which led to the city's fall. Additionally, you'll have the option to select a shorter tour in Hiraizumi so that you can ride a boat in the spectacular Geibikei gorge located not far from the city. Here is a list of the places you will visit: - Motsuji Temple, the site of a massive former temple which has now disappeared almost completely. What remains are a few buildings and treasure halls, but most importantly, the large Buddhist Pure Land garden - a popular scenic spot with special spiritual energy. - Chusonji Temple, a temple complex hidden in the forests just outside central Hiraizumi. Here you will see the Konjikido Hall which is entirely made of gold, similarly to the Golden Pavilion in Kyoto - sadly, taking photos is completely prohibited. - Takadachi Gikeido Hall, which hosts a real-size statue of Minamoto Yoritomo's brother Yoshitsune. His life ended tragically at this place as per his brother's order. - Muryokoin ruins, a former temple grounds where the Fujiwara clan attempted to make a Pure Land garden bigger than Byodoin's one in Kyoto. - Yanagi no Gosho, an open-air historical park where the former Fujiwara residence was located. Optionally, you might want to have a shorter tour in Hiraizumi so that you can visit the nearby Geibikei gorge and take a pleasure boat for a short ride along the spectacular cliffs and natural wonders of the area. Hiraizumi is a place with rich history and important cultural legacy that will make a great addition to your travel itinerary in Japan!
strTitle: Explore the historical sites of Hiraizumi's glorious past

strIntroduction: Iwakuni is a small town in Yamaguchi prefecture, but it's easily accessible from Hiroshima in just 15 minutes by Shinkansen bullet train (or less than an hour with a local train) which makes it a great side trip destination for visitors of Hiroshima and Miyajima island. Iwakuni is also directly connected to Tokyo by air through Iwakuni-Kintaikyo Airport. Although it's a small town, Iwakuni fascinates with its amazing Kintaikyo Bridge, its well-preserved historical area from the Edo period, and its castle built on a top of a hill with a splendid panorama view to the entire surrounding area and the Seto Inland Sea dotted with plenty of small islands. In this half-day guided tour you will see Iwakuni's best attractions: - Kintaikyo Bridge, considered by far Japan's best and most unique bridge. The elegant five arches are made of wood and don't use any nails or wiring. The bridge was originally built in 1673 and survived for nearly 400 years before it was destroyed in the middle of the 20th century by a powerful typhoon. It has been reconstructed and turned into Yamaguchi's symbol and a popular sakura blossom spot. - Kikko Park, a spacious and beautiful park where you can see the legacy of the local feudal lord Kikkawa Hiroyoshi. You will have the chance to enter the ground s of well-preserved samurai residences and visit history museums. There are also other unique places of interest, like a museum of white snakes, believed to bring good luck, and the small farm where cormorants for fishing are kept. - Iwakuni Castle, a castle built in 1608 and destroyed only a few years later. Its present reconstruction on the top of the mountain offers awesome views over the entire town and the Seto Inland Sea. Iwakuni is a great choice for a short trip from Hiroshima and will surely add many new memories from your trip to Japan!
strTitle: See Iwakuni's unique bridge in a short trip from Hiroshima!

strIntroduction: Miyazaki city, the capital of Miyazaki prefecture in Kyushu, is one of Japan's warmest places. Thanks to its vast natural parks, long coastline and mild climate, Miyazaki flourished as a resort destination for couples and honeymoon travelers during the second half of the 20th century. The city also has plenty of attractive spots related to the ancient Japanese myths of the Sun goddess and the creation of the islands. In this private guided tour you will visit some of the city's best attractions: - Miyazaki Jingu Shrine, the oldest shrine in Miyazaki dedicated to the mythical first emperor of Japan - Jimmu. The simple yet attractive building is said to have been constructed 2600 years ago. - Miyazaki Prefectural Museum, which exhibits items related to the mythological history and cultural traditions of the prefecture. Just behind the museum you can see a small open air museum which exhibits several traditional farmhouses. This is one of the best places in the city to learn more about the traditional lifestyle of the ancient people. - Heiwadai Park, a spacious peace park constructed in 1940 to celebrate the 2600th anniversary of the appearance of Japan's first Emperor Jimmu. A giant tower fascinating for its architectural design stands in the middle of the park. Nearby is the Haniwa Garden, a natural spot with over 400 haniwa (ancient clay burial statues) spread across the forest. - Aoshima Island, a splendid little island connected to the beach by a short bridge. Here you can enjoy the dense jungles and find hidden sanctuaries inside, or see the natural geological phenomenon "Devil's Washboard" made of straight lines of basalt rock next to the shoreline. Another famous place of Miyazaki city is the giant Phoenix Seagaia Resort which stretches for over 10 kilometers along the scenic coastline. Here you will find an enormous park, several great resort hotels, hot springs, a golf course, a zoo and other interesting attractions.
strTitle: Relax in the subtropical envrionment of Miyazaki's coastline

strIntroduction: Matsue city is the capital of Shimane prefecture. The city is situated between several lakes, the biggest of which is Lake Shinji, a popular spot for seeing stunning sunset views. Matsue was the home of the Matsudaira feudal clan whose main base was the beautiful black Matsue Castle. The moat and canals around the castle are outstanding and there are attractive pleasure boat rides offered. In this tour you will see some of Matsue's most eminent highlights: - Matsue Castle. It was built in 1611 and served as the base of the Matsudaira clan during the Edo period. This is one of the 11 originally surviving castles and fascinates visitors with its elegant black body. The panorama view from the top floor is quite rewarding. - Horikawa moat. You will take a sightseeing boat around the moats and canals of Matsue Castle's park. During the pleasant ride you will pass along hidden natural spots, impressive bridges and other points of interest. The captain of the boat will even sing a Japanese folklore song! - Shiomi Nawate Street and the Samurai Residence. This is a street with traditional houses and gorgeous pine trees. Here you will find plenty of former samurai residences, one of which is open to visitors and presents the lifestyle of the people from the Edo period. - Lafcadio Hearn's Residence. The Japanese-style house used to be the private residence of Lafcadio Hearn, a traveler and writer from Europe who settled in Japan and married a local woman. He wrote about the Japanese folklore and tales under the pseudonym Koizumi Yakumo. - Meimei-an Tea House. Built in 1779 by the local feudal lord, this place was used for relaxation and meditation. Now you can try Japanese tea with sweets served in the tatami room of the tea house. - Lake Shinji. The sunset over Lake Shinji is considered one of Japan's best views. You can ride a sunset boat with drinks and enjoy the natural beauty from the middle of the lake where nothing can obstruct your view. Matsue is also a good transportation hub for reaching the popular Izumo Taisha Shrine to the west and the Adachi Museum of Art to the east.
strTitle: Enjoy the spectacular sunset from the lake city Matsue!

strIntroduction: Yamaguchi city, the capital of Yamaguchi prefecture, is a place with rich history and traditions. It was the base of the Mori clan who were very active in the events that led to overturning the shogunate and the beginning of the Meiji period. The powerful feudal lords managed to create a distinctive atmosphere of spirituality and cultural traditions in Yamaguchi which was the reason why the city became known as the "Kyoto of the West". In this tour you will take a pleasant walk around some of the most important highlights of Yamaguchi city: - Ichinosaka River, a pleasant river often compared to Kamo River in Kyoto. Its streams pass through an old area full of art museums, shops and pleasant cafes. - Xavier Memorial Church, a big catholic church erected to commemorate the 400th anniversary of the missionary St Francis Xavier's arrival to Yamaguchi. Various religious statues and paintings are exhibited inside the impressive white building. - Yamaguchi Daijingu, the city's own small version of the popular Ise Jingu Shrine in Mie prefecture. The local feudal lord built this sacred shrine copying the original in Ise in an attempt to bring the deities closer. The wooden structures attract with their spirituality and elegant appearance. - Rurikoji Temple, Yamaguchi's best known temple built in 1442 and famous for its five-storey pagoda which is registered as a national treasure and is one of Japan's three most famous pagodas. Around the temple's grounds you'll also find a spacious park, Mori clan's family graves, and a splendid museum about Japan's pagodas. - Saikoutei, a Meiji-period restaurant first opened in 1877. It has been used for decades as an official guesthouse and currently exhibits interesting items from the Meiji period. - Joeiji Temple, a Zen temple known for its beautiful Zen garden designed by the famous landscape architect Sesshu. Here you can sit on the veranda and enjoy the tranquil beauty of the Japanese-style garden. Near Yamaguchi city is Yuda Onsen, a pleasant hot springs town which is said to have been discovered by a fox. Yamaguchi is also a transportation hub for Akiyoshidai Plateau and Cave, one of the prefecture's most famous natural wonder spots.
strTitle: Explore Yamaguchi city, known as the "Kyoto of the West"

strIntroduction: Akita prefecture is located in Tohoku, northern Japan, and attracts with its distinctive folklore traditions, festivals, beautiful women and less explored rural areas. In particular the southern part of Akita offers plenty of sightseeing spots which are easily accessible by Shinkansen bullet train from Tokyo. Although a day trip is possible, it's highly recommended to stay overnight in some of Akita's famous hot springs such as Nyuto Onsen or Tamagawa Onsen. In this guided tour you will visit the samurai town Kakunodate, famous for its well-preserved residences and splendid weeping cherry trees, and Lake Tazawa, a spectacular caldera lake with an interesting ancient legend and rather unique energy spots. During the tour you will see: - Kakunodate's former samurai district, which is one of the best preserved samurai districts in Japan. Many of the former samurai residences are open for visitors. They are surrounded by plenty of greenery and beautiful weeping cherry trees which blossom spectacularly at the end of April and the beginning of May. You can explore the area with a rental kimono for a more authentic experience! - Kakunodate's former merchant district, now turned into an area of old shops, storehouses and small factories for producing local delicacies. The architecture is distinctive and the food products sold can be found only in this place. - Kakunodate's former castle site, located on the top of a mountain overlooking the town and Hinokinai River. From here you can see all the beauty of the town originally built in 1620. - Lake Tazawa, the deepest caldera lake in Japan (423 meters), nestled between the mountain hills of Hachimantai National Park. The lake is known for the legend of Tatsuko, a local girl who wished to be beautiful forever, but was instead turned into a dragon and cursed to live at the bottom of the lake. You can see the famous statue of the girl, as well as popular energy spots and shrines where you can pray for love and beauty. Kakunodate and Lake Tazawa are connected via bullet train (just 1 stop) and a short bus ride, and can be explored in a single day. Additionally, you can take a sightseeing boat across Lake Tazawa and appreciate its unspoiled natural beauty.
strTitle: Discover the rural beauty of Akita's Kakunodate samurai town

strIntroduction: Iga Ueno is a small castle town in Mie prefecture, not far from Nara. It is widely known as the "ninja town" because during the Edo period it used to be the home of the Iga-ryu, one of Japan's two best ninja schools (the other being Koka in Shiga prefecture). Iga Ueno is famous for its spacious parks where all the main sightseeing spots are located. Here you can have the unique experience of renting a ninja costume and dressing like a ninja while walking around the park. This is a private guided tour in which you will visit Iga Ueno's highlights and will have the chance to experience some of the ninja-related activities. Here is the list of places that you will visit with your guide: - Danjiri Kaikan, the musuem of the local Ueno Tenjin Festival (held between October 23-25 every year) where you can see the exhibited giant floats, costumes and demon masks used during the festival. In this place you can also rent a ninja costume for a whole day around the town or just for short to have photos of you taken. - Iga Ninja Museum, a small but outstanding ninja museum which features several exhibition halls with fascinating ninja items displayed, a guided tour around a ninja residence with secret doors and traps, as well as an amusing stage show with ninjas. Here you can also practice your shuriken-throwing skills! - Iga Ueno Castle, a beautiful reconstructed castle, originally built in 1585. It stands on the tallest stone walls of any castle in Japan and is surrounded by many cheery trees and wisterias. - Matsuo Basho memorials. Iga Ueno was the birthplace of Japan's most famous haiku poet and there are many interesting buildings and museums related to his life and works. You can also enter the house where he lived and see the preserved simple interior. - Former Sukodo School, originally built as a school for the children of the samurai during the later decades of the Edo period. Now this interesting place is turned into a museum and you can explore the interior of the former school. Please note that the ninja dress-up experience is not included in the price. You will pay for the facilities in cash on the day of your tour. You can choose between renting a ninja costume for a whole day or just for a photo shoot.
strTitle: Dress like a ninja and visit the ninja museum in Iga Ueno!

strIntroduction: Aizu Wakamatsu is a former castle town that impresses with its historical monuments and traditional buildings. Here you will see a unique castle, attractive samurai residences and nationally famous sake breweries. Here is a list of the best places to visit in Aizu Wakamatsu: - Tsuruga Castle, a beautiful and unique castle with red roof tiles. It was originally built in 1384 and has been owned by several famous warlords throughout the centuries, among them Date Masamune and Toyotomi Hideyoshi, until it became the base of the Aizu feudal domain during the Edo period. The castle was completely destroyed during the Boshin War rebellion against the Meiji government, but was reconstructed in 1965. Nearby you will find a traditional tea house and a big garden with many cherry trees. - Aizu sake breweries. Aizu Wakamatsu is one of Japan's major sake producing regions. There are several top-class sake breweries and museums around the city where you can learn more about the traditions of sake making and taste some of the local brands. - Aizu Bukeyashiki, a splendid former samurai residence with several rooms and gardens. You can see mannequin dolls representing the former inhabitants of this museum. - Iimoriyama, the site of the tragic death of Byakkotai, a group of 20 adolescent boys who committed suicide after seeing their castle in flames during the Boshin War. Here you can see their monuments, tombs, a few interesting wartime memorials from WW2, and a unique spiral pagoda that you can explore from inside! Aizu Wakamatsu is an ideal destination if you're looking for authentic samurai towns with plenty of historical monuments! Explore this town on a day trip with a guide!
strTitle: Discover the samurai city Aizu Wakamatsu on a day trip!

strIntroduction: 【Note: On March 18th, 2016 I'll move from Tokyo to Hiroshima. This menu will be available from March 20th in Hiroshima!】 It is a very exciting experience to create your own drink or soup to become beautiful and healthy. I have the ability to read and understand people through observation. This is a unique opportunity where I will interpret you through your picture to create your individualized recipe. The final recipe is always unique and tasty and makes people happy. Before the Session: I will interpret you through your picture and arrange different key ingredients to create a drink or soup recipe with the best color, taste, and texture for you. Session: 1. Discuss your body conditions you are concerned about. 2. Discuss your mental conditions you are concerned about. 3. Interpret the ingredients in your unique recipe. I will explain the effect of each ingredient. If necessary, I will rearrange the recipe based on our discussions. 4. Recreate your individualized drink or soup recipe. 5. Sample and taste your drink or soup. 6. Receive your final recipe via email. Please note: This session is not a medical treatment.
strTitle: Create an Individualized Drink or Soup to Be Beautiful

strIntroduction: 【Note: On March 18th, 2016 I'll move from Tokyo to Hiroshima. This menu will be available from March 20th in Hiroshima!】 This is an eating experience where I will cook you a meal using healthy ingredients and explain the effects of each ingredient on the body. I'll introduce tips and counsel so you can understand how each ingredient works on your body. You will also be able to enjoy tasting and learning about Japanese sake and the Japanese wine of the month. Vegetarian menus are available. No halal menus are available. Please note: There must be a minimum of 2 people for the experience. Reservations must be made 2 days in advance.
strTitle: Enjoy a Healthy Meal, Japanese Sake, and Wine

strIntroduction: Shizuoka city is the capital of Shizuoka prefecture which stretches along the Pacific coast west of Tokyo. Shizuoka is best known for its spectacular views to Mt Fuji, the southern slopes of which are part of the prefecture, and the most famous local product - green tea. The city and the surrounding beaches offer spectacular views over the Pacific Ocean and Mt Fuji in the distance. Furthermore, Shizuoka city is known as the place where the founder of the Edo shogunate Tokugawa Ieyasu spent his last years. Several different sightseeing spots are directly related to the legacy of Tokugawa. In this tour you will visit some of the most interesting sightseeing spots in Shizuoka city and the surrounding harbor area: - Sumpu Castle and Momijiyama Garden. Here you will see a beautiful park with the ruins of the Sumpu Castle where Tokugawa Ieyasu spent his last years. Part of the castle was reconstructed recently in an attempt to restore the past glory of this place. The gorgeous Momijiyama Garden represents the landscape of Shizuoka prefecture in a miniature (Mt Fuji is represented by a hill overlooking the pond). - Shizuoka Asama Shrine. This large shrine complex took 60 years to construct during the last decades of the Tokugawa rule in the 19th century. Parts of the shrine are registered as important national cultural property. Here you can see an exhibition of items and weapons which belonged to the Tokugawa clan. - Nihondaira Plateau and Kunozan Toshogu Mausoleum. This small mountain rises over the coastal area of the city and offers spectacular views of Suruga Bay and Mt Fuji in the distance. Kunozan Toshogu Shrine is one of the most important Tokugawa Ieyasu's mausoleums, surpassed only by the one in Nikko. The lavishly decorated shrine consists of several buildings and a giant gate. - Shimizu harbor area. An attractive port which you can explore either on foot or by riding the convenient water buses. The waterfront area attracts with entertainment and shopping facilities and fish markets. Enjoy the Sushi Museum inside S-Pulse Dream Plaza mall and eat fresh sushi in the local restaurants. Shizuoka city is about 1 hour ride away from Tokyo on the Shinkansen bullet train and is a great place for a day trip.
strTitle: Enjoy views of Mt Fuji, sushi and large temples in Shizuoka!

strIntroduction: Kochi city, the capital of Kochi prefecture, is located in the southern part of Shikoku island at the Pacific Ocean coast. The small city has a distinctive southern flavor and boasts interesting attractions such as dog fight tournaments and whale watching. Kochi used to be Tosa province, one of the two main provinces (the other being Satsuma, today's Kagoshima) which revolted against the shogunate at the end of the Edo period and played an important role in the historical changes which happened with the beginning of the Meiji era. Sakamoto Ryoma, a national hero with an undeniable contribution to Japan's modernization, was born in Kochi. The city is also known for its seafood delicacies, particularly the "katsuo tataki" dish (lightly broiled raw skipjack tuna fish served with a vinegar sauce) which has now become ubiquitous in Japan. In this tour you will visit some of the most interesting sightseeing spots in Kochi and will learn more about its proud history: - Harimayabashi bridge and central Kochi. This is a small vermilion bridge impressive not for its visuals, but for the "Romeo and Juliet" type of legend between a Buddhist monk and a local girl. The center of the city attracts visitors with its shopping arcades and restaurants where you can eat "tataki katsuo". There are also large streets covered with palm trees and a Sunday market. - Kochi Castle, the stronghold of Tosa province, built in 1601. It is one of the 11 originally surviving Japanese castles and is a great place for seeing sakura cherry blossoms in the spring. - Mt Godaisan, located east of the city's center. Here you will see Chikurinji Temple, one of the 88 temples of the Shikoku Pilgrimage. The impressive five-storey pagoda will surely amaze you. Nearby is a spacious and pleasant botanical garden worth a visit. - Katsurahama Beach, one of Kochi's symbols and most popular scenic spot. At the end of the sandy beach you will reach a beautiful little shrine built over the cliff rocks which offers fantastic views of the Pacific Ocean and the coastline. The large park behind Katsurahama Beach is home to Sakamoto Ryoma's statue, Sakamoto Ryoma's Memorial Museum, and the Tosa Dog Museum where you can see the large dogs which were used for fighting tournaments in the past. Kochi is also the home of the popular Yosakoi dance which mixes traditional Japanese dances with popular contemporary rhythms. You will be able to see plenty of spots suggesting that the city is proud of its Yosakoi tradition which has now spread all over Japan.
strTitle: Explore the attractions of Shikoku's southern capital Kochi

strIntroduction: Hikone is located on the eastern shore of Japan's largest Lake Biwa (Biwako) in Shiga prefecture, not too far from Kyoto. The city is ideal destination for a short day trip from Kyoto and offers plenty of authentic sights for those who are interested in Japanese history and traditional architecture. The city has an impressive castle and former samurai residences. It was the base of the Ii clan - feudal lords who rules this area during the Edo period. In this guided walking tour you will visit several sites related to the town's history of feudal rule: - Hikone Castle, an impressive castle built in 1622 by the Ii clan, and one of only 4 in Japan to be registered as a national treasure. Hikone Castle is also one of the 11 originally surviving Japanese castles. The architecture is impressive and you can enter inside the main building and the turrets. - Genkyuen Garden, a beautiful garden built by the Ii feudal lord as a place for entertainment and relaxation. The garden is spacious and has a big pond and several tea houses. - Former samurai residences, located around the castle. Many of them preserve their original architecture and interior and are open for visitors. They belonged to prominent samurai or merchant families. - Yume Kyobashi Castle Road, a pleasant shopping street with warehouses and traditional-style buildings located south of Hikone Castle. After this nice walking tour, you can return back to Kyoto or take a cruising boat to some of the small islands in Lake Biwa. Please ask your guide for recommendations.
strTitle: Go on a day trip to the samurai city Hikone near Lake Biwa

strIntroduction: Aomori city, the capital of Aomori prefecture, is a pleasant harbor city located at the northernmost bay of Japan's main island Honshu. It used to be the main transportation hub to Hokkaido before the undersea tunnel was opened. Aomori still preserves a charming seaside town atmosphere. This otherwise quiet place becomes extremely popular in the beginning of August when thousands of people from all over Japan and abroad arrive to watch the famous Nebuta festival. Giant paper-made floats parade the streets accompanied by dancers and musicians. The evenings in Aomori are not too hot even in the summer which makes this festival a top destination in August. Regardless of when you plan to visit Aomori, there are plenty of things you can see and do. In this guided tour you will visit the following places of interest: - Sannai Maruyama Iseki, a large archaeological site with well-preserved buildings and structures from the Jomon period (the first historical period of Japan, which ended around year 300 BC). Here you can also see many exhibited items from the daily lives of the Jomon era people. You can try hands-on experiences and eat their typical food. - The Prefectural Art Museum, a unique museum in which the exhibits are placed in giant underground trenches resembling excavation sites. The most famous piece of art is the giant dog statue, which is one of the symbols of Aomori city. - Nebuta Warasse, a spectacular museum about the Nebuta festival, where you can some of the actually used giant floats and learn more about the traditions of the event. - Hakkodamaru museum ship, a former ferry which is now open to visitors to explore. You'll get to enter rare to see places such as the engine room and the vehicle decks which accommodates whole train cars! - Furukawa Fish Market, a local fish market known for the service called "nokkedon", where you can buy a set of tickets and exchange them for various seafood items in order to make a seafood bowl of rice according to your own taste and choice. You will find Aomori city a truly exciting place which has both a countryside spirit and unique facilities.
strTitle: Explore Aomori city and create your own seafood rice bowl!

strIntroduction: Matsuyama is the capital of Ehime prefecture and the biggest city on Shikoku island. The city has a rich culture which stems from its literary traditions - three prominent Japanese writers (Natsume Soseki, Masaoka Shiki and Shiba Ryotaro) have been either born here or featured Matsuyama as the main setting of their works. The city boasts a particularly strong classical spirit seen in its museums, art galleries and historical buildings with impressive architecture. Furthermore Matsuyama has been a prominent hot spring resort since the Meiji period when the outstanding Dogo Onsen was constructed. In this guided tour you will tour some of Matsuyama's classical sites and feel the old spirit of the city. The list of places to visit includes: - Matsuyama Castle, one of the few originally surviving castles in Japan located on the top of a mountain with a great panorama view over the city and Seto Inland Sea. The castle has splendid adjacent gardens and beautiful sakura cherry trees which create a remarkable atmosphere during early April. The approach to Matsuyama Castle includes taking a ropeway, a chair lift or hiking. - Dogo Onsen, the famous bath house built in 1894 and featured in Studio Ghibli's Oscar-winning movie "Spirited Away". The entire area around the classical old building is filled with the spirit of the Meiji period - from the last tram station whose building dates back to 19th century, the Botchan Karakuri Clock which offers a show with figurines every hour, through the charming shopping arcade all the way to the hot spring facilities. Dogo Onsen is a true labyrinth of bathrooms and pools, and there is even a special room for the Imperial family. It's common to see people walking around the streets near Dogo Onsen in yukata. - Ishiteji Temple, a mystical place not far away from Dogo Onsen and one of the 88 temples of the Shikoku Pilgrimage. Behind the main buildings and the pagoda you will find a mystical half-lit cave with Buddhist statues. After exiting from the other end of the cave you will soon reach a spectacular dome-shaped hall in what looks like a forgotten backyard garden. Inside the hall you will find impressive and somewhat scary Buddhist statues. You will also have a walk around the shopping arcades of the city where you will have the chance to buy Ehime prefecture's local specialty - mandarins and other artificially bred citrus fruits, or taste mandarin flavored sweets and ice creams.
strTitle: Travel in time around the historical spots of Matsuyama city

strIntroduction: Takamatsu is the capital of Kagawa prefecture on Shikoku island. The harbor city is a major ferry hub connecting Shikoku with many of the little islands that Seto Inland Sea is known for. Takamatsu was an important castle town during the Edo period when it was ruled by the Matsudaira clan. Here you will see interesting historical monuments, enjoy beautiful scenic views and have the chance to eat Kagawa prefecture's local specialty - Sanuki udon noodles! If you're touring Shikoku or visiting some of the popular islands in Seto Inland Sea (such as Naoshima) to see the permanent exhibitions of the art triennale, Takamatsu city will prove to be a worthwhile stop. Take a tour around the city's highlights which include: - Takamatsu Castle ruins. This is the site of the former Takamatsu Castle built right next to the sea coast. It was destroyed during the Meiji period but a unique reconstruction is taking place and there are plans to restore the castle completely. Here you can learn more about the Matsudaira clan which ruled during the Edo period. - Ritsurin Garden. This is a beautiful and spacious Japanese-style garden located at the foot of nearby Mt Shiun. There are many interesting ponds, bridges, pavilions and tea rooms where you can rest and enjoy the tranquil beauty of one of Japan's most scenic spots. - Sanuki udon noodles at the shopping arcades in downtown Takamatsu. The city boasts Japan's longest covered shopping arcade stretching for several kilometers along the center. Here you can find many restaurants specializing in the local delicacy - Sanuki udon noodles, which you can eat hot in soy-based soup or cold with a special dip. - Shikoku Mura, a great open air museum which exhibits many of Shikoku's famous buildings and structures, including a replica of Iya Valley's famous Kazurabashi vine bridge. This is a great place to visit if you don't have time to tour the entire Shikoku island. - Yashima, a small mountain overlooking Takamatsu and the bay. Its observatory provides fantastic panorama views over the Seto Inland Sea and its islands. Yashima is the site of the heroic battle between Minamoto and Taira clans during the 12th century and you will see many sites related to this event. Yashima Temple, one of the 88 temples of the Shikoku Pilgrimage Route, is located here too. Visitors with kids who wish to stay overnight at Takayama should try booking the special Anpanman room at JR Hotel Clement Takamatsu located at Sunport Takamatsu, the marine promenade next to the port.
strTitle: Visit the best scenic spots of Takamatsu city, Shikoku

strIntroduction: Matsushima bay is famous for its scenic view of many little pine islands scattered off the coast of the small town. Thanks to its natural beauty Matsushima has been chosen as one of the 3 best scenic spots in Japan, together with Miyajima island in Hiroshima and Amanohashidate in northern Kyoto prefecture. Several of the pine-covered islands are connected to the mainland with attractive bridges. Matsushima is also a place of deep spiritual energy as one of Japan's most famous Zen temples, Zuiganji, is located here and fascinates visitors with its cultural artifacts, monuments and splendid natural trail approach. Matsushima is easily accessible from Sendai city as a half-day trip. In this tour your guide will take you to the following places of interest: - Zuiganji Temple, the most famous Zen temple of the Tohoku region, originally built in 828 and developed further by the local feudal lord Date Masamune in the 17th century. The temple fascinates with its natural trail approaches, lined cedar trees and hermit caves. The temple complex itself consists of several buildings, an art museum and a mausoleum. - Entsuin, originally constructed in 1646 as a mausoleum to Date Mitsumune from the ruling Date clan. The temple's highlights are several Japanese and English-style gardens as well its unique incorporation of Western elements in the decoration. - Kanrantei, a medieval-style tea house with impressive tatami-style rooms where you can enjoy a cup of tea and have a short rest. - Matsushima bay - you will see many of the pine-covered islands and even go to some of them by crossing the attractive bridges. Some of the islands have small temples of which Godaido Hall is by far the most impressive with its architecture and decoration. At the end of your tour you can ask your guide to suggest pleasant boat cruises along the pine islands for you.
strTitle: Discover one of Japan's most scenic spots, Matsushima!

strIntroduction: Mt Koya is a mountain at the border of Osaka and Wakayama prefectures. It is the religious and spiritual center of the Shingon Buddhist sect, founded by the famous monk Kobo Daishi (Kukai) in 805 when he started building the impressive Danjo Garan temple complex. Currently there are hundreds of temples, shrines, tombs and graveyards located in the compact mountain area near the center of the little town. This is one of the most sacred place for Buddhists in Japan and is also a prominent destination for pilgrims. Mt Koya is the final spot of the Shikoku Pilgrimage and an important part of the UNESCO registered Kumano-Kodo pilgrimage trails. Mt Koya is ideal for those who want to experience religious practices such as purification, sutra copying or staying overnight at a temple and eating the Buddhist monks' "shojin-ryori" meal. You can join this tour from Osaka or directly at Mt Koya if you have stayed there overnight. Your guide will introduce some of the most important sacred locations of Mt Koya: - Kongobuji Temple, the main temple and head of Shingon Buddhism, originally built by the 16th-century shogun Toyotomi Hideyoshi. Here you can see several beautifully decorated Japanese-style rooms as well as Japan's largest rock garden with rocks brought from Shikoku island. - Danjo Garan, the first temple of Mt Koya, founded by Kobo Daishi himself. This sacred complex consists of several smaller temples, shrines and pagodas. It is home to ancient Buddhist art and priceless statues of Buddhist deities. - Daishi Kyokai, the administrative center of Shingon Buddhism, where you can receive religious purification and copy the Heart sutra with your own hands in silence. - Okunoin Temple and Kobo Daishi's Mausoleum, the most sacred place of Mt Koya. The 2-kilometer long forest trail leads through thousands of graves and tombs from all over the centuries and ends at Kobo Daishi's Mausoleum where he is said to be resting in eternal meditation. This place has a mystical aura and unique spiritual energy. Please note that the transportation is not included. You can buy the convenient 2-day Koyasan World Heritage Pass for 2860 JPY per person and use it as a round trip ticket from Osaka. Unlimited rides on the buses in Mt Koya are included as well. Alternatively, you can take this tour after or before you spend a night staying at a temple in Mt Koya. Note: the transportation expenses of your guide are paid separately.
strTitle: Receive spiritual enlightenment in the sacred Mt Koya

strIntroduction: Furano is undoubtedly one of Japan's most scenic spots, especially in July when thousands of people come to see the beautiful lavender fields that the town is famous for. The amazing violet color covers the fields and hill slopes all around you. You can even ride a tractor among the fields! In this private tour you will see some of Furano's highlights in several hours. Here are the best places of interest: - Farm Tomita, the original place where lavender production in Furano began over 50 years ago. Currently the farm has several flower fields and two lavender fields which are best seen in July. There are also restaurants, shops and a small museum building where you can learn more about the history behind lavender cultivation in Hokkaido. - Furano Cheese Factory, where you can observe the process of cheese production. Hokkaido is well-known for its cheese and milk products and this factory has also a shop where you can buy plenty of delicious local products. - Furano Winery, a historical winery where you can learn more about the traditions of wine production in the region and taste local brands. The best time to take this tour is between June and late August when thousands of different flowers are blooming over the rural fields of Furano. Note that the itinerary changes according to the duration of the tour. The above itinerary is for a 2-hour tour. Please ask for different itineraries and duration.
strTitle: See the natural beauty of the lavender paradise Furano!

strIntroduction: This is a special tour only available in late March and early April. The sakura cherry is the most famous Japanese flower and it's a tradition to make sakura picnics (hanami) during the spring. People eat and drink under the blooming cherry trees. The delicate pink color of the flower petals will fascinate you! Ueno Park is one of the best spots to see sakura cherry blossoms in Tokyo. Here you can find also many food stalls and try Japanese food during the sakura season. You will also ride a boat on Shinobazu Lake and see ducks and other water birds from a short distance. Finally, you will walk along Ame-Yoko shopping street where you can try popular Japanese delicacies and buy souvenir gifts. Enjoy your time in Ueno to the fullest with this tour! All participants will receive a commemorative photo as a present!
strTitle: Go on a sakura cherry blossoms tour around Ueno!

strIntroduction: Okayama is a place rich in history and legends. Here you will see the legacy of the local feudal lords which ruled the city and the prefecture during the Edo period by visiting the impressive Okayama Castle and Korakuen, one of Japan's best gardens. You will also learn about the legend of Prince Kibitsuhiko who freed the local kingdom from the oppressive rule of an evil ogre and will tour several related shrines in the rural fields of Kibi just outside Okayama city. In this pleasant day guided day tour you will visit the following places: - Korakuen Garden, widely known as one of Japan's best three gardens (together with Kenrokuen in Kanazawa and Kairakuen in Mito). The garden was constructed in 1687 by an order of the local feudal lord. It features a large pond, impressive lawns, cherry trees, plum trees, rice paddies and tea rooms. - Okayama Castle, built in 1597 by the feudal lord Ukita Hideie. The castle impresses with its large black building and interior. Many interesting exhibits can be found inside. - Kibitsuhiko Shrine, a mystical place amidst the rural fields where Prince Kibitsuhiko prayed before he chased the evil ogre. - Kibitsu Shrine, another mystical place where the Prince attacked and defeated the ogre. The last two spots are located in the scenic Kibi Fields and you can tour them on a bicycle or by a pleasant hour-long walk among the fields.
strTitle: Discover the history and legends of Okayama!

strIntroduction: Oita prefecture in Kyushu is widely known as the "hot spring prefecture" of Japan. It has the biggest amount of natural hot springs and the biggest amount of hot water gushing out of the ground per hour in the entire country. Oita's leading hot spring resort is Beppu, a pleasant little city with a mild climate on the east cost of Kyushu island. It has a total of 8 different hot spring areas which are used by many hotels, inns and bath facilities. The view of white steam coming out of the vents at random spots around the city is truly impressive! Beppu is blessed with various types of hot spring facilities - thermal water baths, sand baths, steam baths and mud baths. Local people often stop by a hot spring after work for relaxation and socialization. In this guided tour you will first visit the most famous attraction of Beppu - the 8 Hells where visitors can enjoy a variety of spectacular views and see interesting facilities. Touring those 8 natural hot spring wonders has been popular for decades and is the reason why the first guided bus tours in Japan originated from Beppu. The Hells are: - Umi Jigoku (Sea Hell) - a stunningly beautiful blue pond covered in white steam. The greenhouse garden nearby is worth a visit and the giant lotus flowers in another clear-water pond create a peaceful atmosphere. - Oniishibozu Jigoku (Monk head Hell) - a pool of round-shaped mud bubbles. There is a foot bath too. - Shiraike Jigoku (White pond Hell) - a pond with milky water and a small aquarium with some rare Amazon river fish. - Kamado JIgoku (Pot Hell) - here you can try eggs or pudding made on the hot steam - Oniyama Jigoku (Demon Mountain Hell) - this pond's temperature is nearly 100 degrees and there are separate pools with crocodiles next to the hot springs. - Yama Jigoku (Mountain Hell) - it features a small zoo next to the hot water pond. - Chinoike Jigoku (Blood Hell) - a scary-looking red water pond - Tatsumaki Jigoku (Spout Hell) - a natural hot geyser which erupts spectacularly once every 30-40 minutes. After touring the 8 Hells, you will go to the top of Mt Tsurumi, a 1375-meter tall mountain overlooking the city. The ropeway ride to the top reveals plenty of scenic spots. You can walk around some trails at the top and enjoy the beautiful nature of Oita prefecture before returning back to the city.
strTitle: Tour the hot steam Hells of Beppu city!

strIntroduction: Sendai in Miyagi prefecture is the biggest and most important city in Tohoku region, Japan's northeast. The city was the home of the powerful Date clan which ruled the area for centuries as feudal lords. Date Masamune, the founder of the clan, is one of the most important historical figures in Japan and this tour will take you to many places related to him and his successors. The devastating 2011 Tohoku Earthquake had it epicenter off the coast of Sendai but the city surprisingly did not suffer much damage and the cultural properties remain intact. In this day tour you will visit the most attractive sightseeing spots in Sendai. The following is an example of the places included: - Zuihoden Mausoleum. This is the lavishly decorated mausoleum where the tombs of Date Masamune and his successor are situated. Although the mausoleum isn't big, it fascinates with its Momoyama period-style architecture and colourful decoration. The approach includes passing a path with many cedar trees. In the nearby museum you can see a display of important belongings of the Date clan. - Sendai Castle ruins. Date Masamune built his castle on the top of Mt Aoba overlooking Sendai city. Unfortunately, the castle didn't survive the wars and fire disasters and now there are only historical ruins left from its previous glory. Nevertheless, the view from the top is spectacular and Date Masamune's bronze statue is a symbol of Sendai. - Ichibancho. This is one of the longest covered shopping street areas in northern Japan. There are plenty of grocery shops, boutiques and restaurants where you can have lunch. Don't forget to try Sendai's most famous specialty - grilled beef tongue called "Gyu-tan"! Despite being fully covered, the shopping arcade has plenty of planted trees which reflects the image of Sendai as a "city of trees". - Rinnoji Temple. This temple is located in Sendai's outskirts and was founded in the 15th century by a member of the Date clan. A long stone-paved road leads to the main temple hall. Beyond the hall visitors are surprised by a very beautiful Japanese-style garden with a pond, and a three-storey pagoda. Plenty of seasonal flowers bloom throughout the year. - AER Building observatory. This free observation deck on the top of the centrally located AER Building offers a fantastic view over Sendai's downtown. If you visit the city in early August you will be stunned by the massive decorative streamers put everywhere around the center in preparation for the annual Tanabata Festival. Sendai can be visited as a day trip from Tokyo and is a great place to explore if you're interested in Japan's history and culture.
strTitle: Discover the historical legacy of Sendai's Daté samurai clan

strIntroduction: Kobe shares similarity with other famous port cities in Japan which quickly developed after the end of the Edo period and the opening of the country to foreign merchants and residents. The similarity with Yokohama is particularly striking, as both cities have a Chinatown, a foreign residences hill and a large attractive seaside area with plenty of entertainment and shopping facilities. Kobe became internationally known in 1995 when it was badly hit by a powerful earthquake. This resulted in over 5000 casualties and thousands of destroyed buildings. Luckily, the city recovered quickly and now only an intentionally preserved lane in the seaside park reminds visitors of the tragedy that happened. A large Earthquake Museum was also opened to educate travelers about the recovery efforts of local people. In this private guided tour you can choose between two different itineraries which focus on different city highlights: Course A: In this itinerary you will visit the following sites: - Akashi Kaikyo Bridge. This is the world's longest suspension bridge which connects Honshu island with Awaji Island. There is a special Exhibition Center at the foot of the bridge, as well as a unique Marine Promenade hallway under the main platform where you can walk above the water! (closed every second Monday of the month) - Chinatown. Otherwise known as Nanking Town, this is one of Japan's best three Chinatowns (together with Yokohama's and Nagasaki's ones) - Meriken Park and Kobe Tower. This is a popular seaside park where you can enjoy modern architecture and leisurely time strolling along the marine promenades. The view from Kobe Tower's observatory is splendid! - Harborland. In this popular shopping and amusement area you can find souvenir gifts and other interesting goods. - Mt Rokko Observatory. The night view to Kobe from Mt Rokko is widely known as the "10-million dollar view". You will be left speechless upon seeing this stunningly beautiful night view! Course B: In this itinerary you will visit the following sites: - Nada Sake District. You will be able to visit one of the publicly open sake breweries in Japan's best sake producing region. Sake tasting is available. - Chinatown. Otherwise known as Nanking Town, this is one of Japan's best three Chinatowns (together with Yokohama's and Nagasaki's ones) - Kitano-cho. This is the area of the foreign residences, similar to Yamate Hill in Yokohama. Dozens of foreign merchants, diplomats and wealthy families built their Western-style residences in the end of the 19th century. Now Kitano-cho is a beautiful area with a strong international flavor. You can enter many of the former residences which have been turned into museums. - Mt Rokko Observatory. The night view to Kobe from Mt Rokko is widely known as the "10-million dollar view". You will be left speechless upon seeing this stunningly beautiful night view! Of course, the tour can be customized according to your preferences, so don't hesitate to let us know which places you'd like to visit in Kobe!
strTitle: Explore the beautiful port city Kobe with a private guide
